articles.headline: ‘Justice for Laquan!’ Demonstrators Chant, as Chicago Officer Is Convicted of Murder
articles.snippet: For some residents, the trial of Officer Jason Van Dyke in the killing of Laquan McDonald became a proxy for years of anger over police mistreatment of black Chicagoans.
articles.abstract: For some residents, the trial of Officer Jason Van Dyke in the killing of Laquan McDonald became a proxy for years of anger over police mistreatment of black Chicagoans.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For three years, Chicago was racked by the political, legal and emotional impact of a chilling video that lasted only seconds: A black teenager could be seen collapsing onto a street as a white police officer shot him over and over, 16 times in the end.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith, Timothy Williams and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Ford, an Automaker at a Crossroads, Seeks Cuts and Partners
articles.snippet: With its stock at its lowest point since 2009, the company plans to trim its salaried work force and is exploring an alliance with Volkswagen.
articles.abstract: With its stock at its lowest point since 2009, the company plans to trim its salaried work force and is exploring an alliance with Volkswagen.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — When Ford Motor was celebrating the 100th anniversary of its Rouge industrial complex last week, its chairman, William C. Ford Jr., offered an optimistic outlook for the years ahead.

articles.headline: Susan Collins, Standing Alone, Makes Her Case for Kavanaugh
articles.snippet: The Republican senator from Maine delivered a 45-minute, point-by-point civics lesson of a speech to explain her support for President Trump’s nominee.
articles.abstract: The Republican senator from Maine delivered a 45-minute, point-by-point civics lesson of a speech to explain her support for President Trump’s nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Susan Collins was on her own.

articles.headline: After Lots of Bluster, Trump Has a Week to Brag About
articles.snippet: But in Mr. Trump’s scorched-earth presidency, the victories — whether the success of Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination or the trade deal with Canada and Mexico — are divisive and come at a cost.
articles.abstract: But in Mr. Trump’s scorched-earth presidency, the victories — whether the success of Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination or the trade deal with Canada and Mexico — are divisive and come at a cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He promised so much success that everyone would be tired of all the winning. But after 20 months that proved more arduous than President Trump once imagined, this may be the best week of his presidency so far.

articles.headline: Bitter Tenor of Senate Reflects a Nation at Odds With Itself
articles.snippet: The battle over the confirmation of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh has exposed a climate of partisan distrust rivaled by few other moments in the recent past.
articles.abstract: The battle over the confirmation of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh has exposed a climate of partisan distrust rivaled by few other moments in the recent past.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he helped speed Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s embattled nomination toward a vote this week, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, declared that the Senate was approaching “rock bottom” and needed to right itself.

articles.headline: U.S. General Considered Nuclear Response in Vietnam War, Cables Show
articles.snippet: In 1968, a top American military commander wanted to move nuclear weapons to South Vietnam to prevent defeat in a key battle. President Johnson refused.
articles.abstract: In 1968, a top American military commander wanted to move nuclear weapons to South Vietnam to prevent defeat in a key battle. President Johnson refused.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of the darkest moments of the Vietnam War, the top American military commander in Saigon activated a plan in 1968 to move nuclear weapons to South Vietnam until he was overruled by President Lyndon B. Johnson, according to recently declassified documents cited in a new history of wartime presidential decisions.

articles.headline: Confirming Kavanaugh: A Triumph for Conservatives, but a Blow to the Court’s Image
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will move further to the right than it has been in many decades, with two distinct blocs that reflect the deep polarization of the American public and political system.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will move further to the right than it has been in many decades, with two distinct blocs that reflect the deep polarization of the American public and political system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump and for Senate Republicans, confirming Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh as a Supreme Court justice was a hard-won political victory. But for the conservative legal movement, it is a signal triumph, the culmination of a decades-long project that began in the Reagan era with the heady goal of capturing a solid majority on the nation’s highest court.

articles.headline: In Disaster’s Grip, Again and Again, on Indonesian Island
articles.snippet: The earthquake and tsunami that devastated Indonesia’s Sulawesi Island struck a place where every kind of catastrophe — natural and man-made — has piled on, and help is far away.
articles.abstract: The earthquake and tsunami that devastated Indonesia’s Sulawesi Island struck a place where every kind of catastrophe — natural and man-made — has piled on, and help is far away.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIGI, Indonesia — The sun was setting on the mosque in Sigi, and Randi Renaldi, 7, knelt and reached his fingers out in supplication. Then the ground beneath him juddered and swayed.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono

articles.headline: Kavanaugh Is Sworn In After Close Confirmation Vote in Senate
articles.snippet: His elevation locked in a solid conservative majority on the Supreme Court and capped a rancorous battle.
articles.abstract: His elevation locked in a solid conservative majority on the Supreme Court and capped a rancorous battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh was confirmed to the Supreme Court on Saturday by one of the slimmest margins in American history, locking in a solid conservative majority on the court and capping a rancorous battle that began as a debate over judicial ideology and concluded with a national reckoning over sexual misconduct.

articles.headline: Show How You Feel, Kavanaugh Was Told, and a Nomination Was Saved
articles.snippet: Judge Kavanaugh’s angry Senate testimony, urged by the White House counsel, Don McGahn, turned the tables and emboldened demoralized Republicans.
articles.abstract: Judge Kavanaugh’s angry Senate testimony, urged by the White House counsel, Don McGahn, turned the tables and emboldened demoralized Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh sat in the anteroom of Room 216 in the Hart Senate Office Building, a sterile, living-room-like space with a couch and a couple of armchairs and a large television on the wall. His chances of joining the Supreme Court seemed to be vanishing. “Disaster,” read the text message from one Republican.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Jamal Khashoggi Disappears, a Mystery Rattling the Middle East
articles.snippet: A Saudi dissident has not been seen since he entered the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on Tuesday. Turkey says he was killed there. Saudi officials deny it.
articles.abstract: A Saudi dissident has not been seen since he entered the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on Tuesday. Turkey says he was killed there. Saudi officials deny it.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jamal Khashoggi, a prominent Saudi dissident, met two friends for lunch last Monday in London to discuss a newspaper column he had drafted lamenting the lack of free speech in the Arab world. “Everyone is fearful,” he wrote.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: How a Potential $1 Billion Student Loan Settlement Collapsed After Trump Won
articles.snippet: Talks between the big student debt collector and the government broke down after President Trump’s victory. Now Navient is making its case not just in court but in person.
articles.abstract: Talks between the big student debt collector and the government broke down after President Trump’s victory. Now Navient is making its case not just in court but in person.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the final months of President Obama’s administration, the government’s top consumer regulator was negotiating a large settlement with the student loan collector Navient, which it said had misled borrowers and made mistakes that added billions of dollars to their bills.

articles.headline: Wall Street Is Booming Under Trump. But Many of Its Donors Are Embracing Democrats.
articles.snippet: The financial community is on pace to give more money to Democratic congressional candidates and incumbents than their Republican counterparts.
articles.abstract: The financial community is on pace to give more money to Democratic congressional candidates and incumbents than their Republican counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Charles Myers, the chairman of a financial advisory firm, hosted four relatively unknown Democratic congressional candidates at his Midtown Manhattan home last month, he netted more money than he can remember collecting from an event that wasn’t headlined by a presidential candidate.

articles.headline: Tech Workers Now Want to Know: What Are We Building This For?
articles.snippet: Tech employees concerned their products are being deployed for government surveillance or censorship are increasingly asking their employers how the technology is being used.
articles.abstract: Tech employees concerned their products are being deployed for government surveillance or censorship are increasingly asking their employers how the technology is being used.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jack Poulson, a Google research scientist, recently became alarmed by reports that the company was developing a search engine for China that would censor content on behalf of the government.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Investors Shunned Juul, but Back Other Nicotine Start-Ups
articles.snippet: The willingness to back some nicotine start-ups while condemning others illustrates the delicate ethical dance that investors are trying to perform.
articles.abstract: The willingness to back some nicotine start-ups while condemning others illustrates the delicate ethical dance that investors are trying to perform.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley’s investors have put their money in plenty of ethically dubious companies, including those that make addictive apps, surveillance technology or services that knowingly exploit legal gray areas.

articles.headline: China Wants to Strike Back on Trade. Big U.S. Deals Could Suffer.
articles.snippet: Disney-Fox and United Technologies-Rockwell Collins could face scrutiny from Beijing, but it is not clear if regulators are affected by trade tensions.
articles.abstract: Disney-Fox and United Technologies-Rockwell Collins could face scrutiny from Beijing, but it is not clear if regulators are affected by trade tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Qualcomm, the American chip maker, spent two years hammering out a $44 billion deal to acquire a Dutch semiconductor manufacturer. Then, as the trade war with the United States erupted, Chinese regulators effectively killed it.

articles.headline: Brazil Election: Jair Bolsonaro Heads to Runoff After Missing Outright Win
articles.snippet: Fed up with corruption and violence, Brazilians tilted toward the far-right candidate and his promise of an iron fist. He will face Fernando Haddad of the Workers’ Party.
articles.abstract: Fed up with corruption and violence, Brazilians tilted toward the far-right candidate and his promise of an iron fist. He will face Fernando Haddad of the Workers’ Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A far-right candidate who has spoken fondly of Brazil’s onetime military dictatorship came close to an outright victory in the country’s presidential election on Sunday, as Brazilians expressed disgust with politics as usual and endorsed an iron-fisted approach to fighting crime and corruption.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Manuela Andreoni

articles.headline: Court Battle Shifts Political Terrain for Senators in Heartland
articles.snippet: In North Dakota and other farm states, the heated debate over the Supreme Court has nationalized the fight for the Senate, elating Republicans and worrying Democrats.
articles.abstract: In North Dakota and other farm states, the heated debate over the Supreme Court has nationalized the fight for the Senate, elating Republicans and worrying Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUTLAND, N.D. — When Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat, and her Republican opponent, Representative Kevin Cramer, put Sunday’s annual Uffda Day celebration on their schedules this year, they most likely thought they would get an earful from voters about tariffs here in the heart of North Dakota’s soybean belt.

articles.headline: As Storms Keep Coming, FEMA Spends Billions in ‘Cycle’ of Damage and Repair
articles.snippet: FEMA has paid out billions for disaster recovery efforts. But many projects seem to be undertaken in defiance of climate change, leaving structures nearly as vulnerable as before.
articles.abstract: FEMA has paid out billions for disaster recovery efforts. But many projects seem to be undertaken in defiance of climate change, leaving structures nearly as vulnerable as before.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVANT, La. — In the exact spot where Hurricane Katrina demolished the Plaquemines Parish Detention Center, a new $105 million jail now hovers 19 feet above the marsh, perched atop towering concrete pillars. Described by a state official as the “Taj Mahal” of Louisiana corrections, it has so much space that one of every 27 parish residents could bunk there.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Pensions Get Bolder in Challenging Private Equity on Investments’ Human Cost
articles.snippet: Public funds are flexing their financial might with private equity on issues from severance for Toys “R” Us workers to workplace harassment.
articles.abstract: Public funds are flexing their financial might with private equity on issues from severance for Toys “R” Us workers to workplace harassment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity firms and public pension funds have long had a symbiotic relationship: The funds supply the firms with billions of dollars to invest, and the firms deliver double-digit returns that help the funds support retired public servants.

articles.headline: Former Trump Aide Hope Hicks to Join Fox as Communications Chief
articles.snippet: As the Murdoch media empire undergoes a dramatic change, it turns to the president’s former communications director.
articles.abstract: As the Murdoch media empire undergoes a dramatic change, it turns to the president’s former communications director.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Murdoch family, in the throes of reshaping its media empire, is bringing on a lieutenant with experience in chaotic environments: President Trump’s former communications director, Hope Hicks.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: In a Mississippi Restaurant, Two Americas Coexist Side by Side
articles.snippet: Amid fried catfish and sweet tea, two friends in Mississippi, who agree on next to nothing about politics, navigate their differences as part of their daily shifts.
articles.abstract: Amid fried catfish and sweet tea, two friends in Mississippi, who agree on next to nothing about politics, navigate their differences as part of their daily shifts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTHAVEN, Miss. — Crystal Walls and Lovetta Green have the easy warmth that comes with working together 23 years, Ms. Walls as a waitress and Ms. Green in the kitchen of the restaurant where everyone in town seems to gather.
articles.byline: By Susan Chira and Ellen Ann Fentress
